content:
There's several ways to characterise a constant morphism c:B→Cc : B \to Cc:B→C in category theory. For instance, as a morphism factoring through a terminal object, or as a morphism with the property that for every other AAA, at most one morphism A→CA \to CA→C factors through it. In the category Set\mathbf{Set}Set this reduces to a constant function.

But I'm interested in the analogous property of dependent functions. That is, I want to understand when is a dependent function (a:A)→B(a)(a : A) \to B(a)(a:A)→B(a) constant, for some suitable meaning of this word. I come at this question from studying irrelevance/erasure in type theory, where we study maps like (0a:A)→B(a)(0 a : A) \to B(a)(0a:A)→B(a) - meaning the aaa can only influence the type of the codomain, but not the value.

Is something know about a possible characterisation of such function, analogous to characterisations of the non-dependent case?

I should also add that for (0a:A)→B(a)(0 a : A) \to B(a)(0a:A)→B(a) I'm specifically interested in cases when B:A→SetB : A \to \mathbf{Set}B:A→Set itself is not constant - otherwise the whole situation trivialises.

Here's one example of such a function (implemented in Idris 2)

f : (0 a : Type) -> (n : Nat ** Vect n a)
f _ = (0 ** Nil)

Another way to think about this is that for the non-dependent case for all b,b′:Bb, b' : Bb,b′:B it holds that c(b)=c(b′)c(b) = c(b')c(b)=c(b′).
But generalising this to the dependent case grounds to a halt - the results c(b):B(b)c(b) : B(b)c(b):B(b) and c(b′):B(b′)c(b') : B(b')c(b′):B(b′) are of different types!

It looks like we might need to use some notion of heterogeneous equality. However, on nLab the part about its categorical semantics is unfortunately empty :face_with_diagonal_mouth:

the exact types for which axiom K (https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/axiom+K+%28type+theory%29) contradicts univalence is studied in homotopy type theory. the categorical semantics of heterogenous equality may just be under-developed; here's a setoid model of 'observational type theory', which admits axiom K: https://hal.inria.fr/hal-03367052/document

Unfortunately, if you want to study the semantics of such functions, we need to understand what your categorical semantics for dependent types are first! Are you working with choices of fibrations in some category C C C?

you might want to look into shape-irrelevance: basically, if you want to be able to form (0 a : A) → B a, B must already be shape-irrelevant in its argument. This means that for two unrelated inputs x and y, B x and B y are related, and for types in the universe this roughly means that they support some heterogeneous equality. Once you have that heterogeneous equality, you can state what being constant is!
for some references, you can look into paramdtt (https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3110276) or Andreas Nuyts' thesis in general.
see also https://arxiv.org/abs/1706.04383 for a model

Josselin Poiret said:

Unfortunately, if you want to study the semantics of such functions, we need to understand what your categorical semantics for dependent types are first! Are you working with choices of fibrations in some category C C C?

I'm working with what I thought was the categorical semantics for dependent types, which is the one given by slice categories, i.e. where objects in C/A\mathcal{C}/AC/A are interpeted as types depending on AAA. Actually, the whole reason I'm asking this question is because I'm trying to understand categorical semantics of erased dependent types.
In other words, if a morphism between indexed types X,Y:A→SetX, Y : A \to \mathbf{Set}X,Y:A→Set i.e. a map of type (a:A)→X(a)→Y(a)(a : A) \to X(a) \to Y(a)(a:A)→X(a)→Y(a) corresponds to a morphism in C/A\mathcal{C}/AC/A, then what does an analogous zero-annotated morphism (0a:A)→X(a)→Y(a)(0 a : A) \to X(a) \to Y(a)(0a:A)→X(a)→Y(a) correspond to? Can it be expressed as a map in some slice category?
I don't think it means anything in the absence of extra structure (perhaps on C, or on X and Y).
For example take C = Set and A = 2. Suppose I have a random type family presented by a map X→2X \to 2X→2. What does it mean for a section of it to be "constant"?
I can independently replace the two fibers with isomorphic sets without changing the original map (up to isomorphism), so there doesn't seem to be any nontrivial way to define it.

On the other hand if you represent your family by a function from 222 to the class of all ZFC sets, then you can say what it means: it means the two values of the function are equal (as ZFC sets).
Categorically this means we gave extra data: not just two sets, but also their intersection.
I believe similar situations (e.g. "phase distinctions") have been analyzed using modalities; I'm not sure of the exact relationship to your question though.
In Idris, can you do anything with one of these (0 a : A) -> B a functions that you can't do with an ordinary function?

Bruno Gavranovic said:

Josselin Poiret said:

Unfortunately, if you want to study the semantics of such functions, we need to understand what your categorical semantics for dependent types are first! Are you working with choices of fibrations in some category C C C?

I'm working with what I thought was the categorical semantics for dependent types, which is the one given by slice categories, i.e. where objects in C/A\mathcal{C}/AC/A are interpeted as types depending on AAA. Actually, the whole reason I'm asking this question is because I'm trying to understand categorical semantics of _erased_ dependent types.
In other words, if a morphism between indexed types X,Y:A→SetX, Y : A \to \mathbf{Set}X,Y:A→Set i.e. a map of type (a:A)→X(a)→Y(a)(a : A) \to X(a) \to Y(a)(a:A)→X(a)→Y(a) corresponds to a morphism in C/A\mathcal{C}/AC/A, then what does an analogous zero-annotated morphism (0a:A)→X(a)→Y(a)(0 a : A) \to X(a) \to Y(a)(0a:A)→X(a)→Y(a) correspond to? Can it be expressed as a map in some slice category?

depending on who you ask, this is not well behaved: the action of substitutions on dependent types is not functorial! Also, you might ask for your dependent types to not just be morphisms X→A X → A X→A but fibrations in some specific model category/category of fibrations/tribes/etc.

Maybe I am missing something, but if X:Γ.X→ΓX: \Gamma.X \rightarrow \GammaX:Γ.X→Γ is a dependent type, then isn't a term (section) t:Γ→Γ.Xt: \Gamma \rightarrow \Gamma.Xt:Γ→Γ.X constant if there exists a morphism (substitution) f:1→Γf: 1 \rightarrow \Gammaf:1→Γ and a section c:1→1×ΓΓ.Xc: 1 \rightarrow 1 \times_\Gamma \Gamma.Xc:1→1×Γ​Γ.X of f∗X:1×ΓΓ.X→1f^*X: 1 \times_\Gamma \Gamma.X \rightarrow 1f∗X:1×Γ​Γ.X→1 such that t=π2c!Γt = \pi_2 c !_\Gammat=π2​c!Γ​.
like @Reid Barton mentioned above, most categorical semantics of type theory is data, you have to chose how to represent the different moving parts of the type theory using category theory

Sam Speight said:

Maybe I am missing something, but if X:Γ.X→ΓX: \Gamma.X \rightarrow \GammaX:Γ.X→Γ is a dependent type, then isn't a term (section) t:Γ→Γ.Xt: \Gamma \rightarrow \Gamma.Xt:Γ→Γ.X constant if there exists a morphism (substitution) f:1→Γf: 1 \rightarrow \Gammaf:1→Γ and a section c:1→1×ΓΓ.Xc: 1 \rightarrow 1 \times_\Gamma \Gamma.Xc:1→1×Γ​Γ.X of f∗X:1×ΓΓ.X→1f^*X: 1 \times_\Gamma \Gamma.X \rightarrow 1f∗X:1×Γ​Γ.X→1 such that t=π2c!Γt = \pi_2 c !_\Gammat=π2​c!Γ​.

π2c!Γ\pi_2 c !_\Gammaπ2​c!Γ​ will not be a section (unless Γ\GammaΓ is a singleton). After composing with XXX, everything is sent to the image of ccc.

Reid Barton said:

In Idris, can you do anything with one of these (0 a : A) -> B a functions that you can't do with an ordinary function?

I think it's rather the opposite, just like with parametricity you have less irrelevant functions, and you can deduce theorems for them either meta-theoretically or internally if you have some internal parametricity theorem (which I don't think is the case in Iris). I guess the meta-theoretical results can be important to deduce optimizations like erasure when extracting code

Reid Barton said:

Maybe I am missing something, but if X:Γ.X→ΓX: \Gamma.X \rightarrow \GammaX:Γ.X→Γ is a dependent type, then isn't a term (section) t:Γ→Γ.Xt: \Gamma \rightarrow \Gamma.Xt:Γ→Γ.X constant if there exists a morphism (substitution) f:1→Γf: 1 \rightarrow \Gammaf:1→Γ and a section c:1→1×ΓΓ.Xc: 1 \rightarrow 1 \times_\Gamma \Gamma.Xc:1→1×Γ​Γ.X of f∗X:1×ΓΓ.X→1f^*X: 1 \times_\Gamma \Gamma.X \rightarrow 1f∗X:1×Γ​Γ.X→1 such that t=π2c!Γt = \pi_2 c !_\Gammat=π2​c!Γ​.

π2c!Γ\pi_2 c !_\Gammaπ2​c!Γ​ will not be a section (unless Γ\GammaΓ is a singleton). After composing with XXX, everything is sent to the image of ccc.

Oh yea now I see the nuance of the problem.
